column5: Business Rule

column4: The process description indicates that scanning the ticket first is the standard industry procedure to gather the necessary passenger information before handling change requests. This is not mandated by law nor a rigid business rule, but rather a generally accepted best practice.
column6: There is a data dependency between scanning the ticket and changing the number of bags, as the latter requires the information obtained from the former. However, this data dependency does not make the ordering an absolute, inviolable law of nature.

column4: The process description indicates that scanning the ticket first to obtain the passenger information is an accepted and standard practice, even though it is not strictly required. This suggests it is a best practice rather than a governmental law or business rule.

column5: The process description indicates that the airline has a business rule to only proceed with the check-in process if the ticket and documents are valid. Scanning the ticket first allows them to retrieve the passenger information and check the validity before investing time in the rest of the process.

column4: The process indicates that scanning the ticket first is more efficient and preferred by the staff, even though they sometimes do check the weight first. This suggests that scanning the ticket first is a widely accepted and superior procedure, even if not strictly required.

column5: The process description indicates that the order of Scan Ticket before Cancel Check-in is a rule set by the airline/organization, and not mandated by any governmental law or industry-wide best practice. It is a business decision made by the stakeholders to ensure that they do not waste time on invalid tickets or passports, and to stop the process immediately if the initial scan identifies any issues.

The process description states that 'the airline wants us to only do the check-in if the other things are done to make sure that the payment is processed.' This indicates that the ordering of Scan Ticket before Process Payment is a rule set by the airline, which has full jurisdiction over this aspect of the process. The airline can change or discard this rule at their own discretion.

The process description indicates that the airline wants the check-in to be done only after the ticket has been scanned, suggesting this is a rule or requirement set by the airline, which is within their jurisdiction as the stakeholder of the process.
The process description states that the airline wants the check-in to be done before the luggage is loaded, indicating this is a rule set by the airline as the main stakeholder of the process.

The airline has decided that they need to have the passenger information, including the number of bags, before they can proceed to check the validity of the documents. This is an internal business requirement rather than being mandated by external laws or industry practices.

column4: The process description indicates that changing the number of bags before weighing the baggage is a common and accepted practice in the industry, even though it is not mandated by any external source.

column5: The process description suggests that the ordering of these two activities is a rule set by the airline itself. It states 'Important is that after canceling a checkin instance, you should not perform any other activities.' This implies that the airline has decided that changing the number of bags should occur before canceling the check-in, likely to maintain data integrity and avoid unnecessary work.

The order of these two activities is a rule that is under the full jurisdiction of the airline stakeholders. They have the ability to change or discard this rule at their own discretion, as it is an internal policy of the airline.
The airline has established this as an internal procedure to manage the logistics of the check-in process and charge any additional fees for changes to the number of bags.

The process description states that the airline wants the change in the number of bags to be handled before the luggage is loaded onto the aircraft. This is a rule that is under the full jurisdiction of the airline, and they can choose to change or discard this rule at their own discretion.

column4: The process description indicates that changing the seat is a standard procedure that is accepted by the organization's staff and industry-wide, and checking the validity of documents is then performed after the seat has been changed, likely as a best practice to ensure the passenger's information is up-to-date and valid before proceeding.

The process description indicates that the best practice is to make any seat changes before canceling the check-in, as performing other activities after a cancellation would be inefficient or undesirable.

column5: The process description states that the airline 'wants us to only do the check-in if the other things are done to make sure that the payment is processed.' This implies that the ordering of Change seat before Process payment is a rule set by the airline, which is the main stakeholder in this process.

The process description states that the airline wants the Change seat activity to be completed before the Check-in luggage activity, indicating that this is a rule set by the airline itself, which has full jurisdiction over how the process is structured.

column4: It is a standard procedure in the airline industry to update the seat information before loading the luggage to ensure the passenger information is accurate, even though it is not a mandatory requirement enforced by any stakeholder or governmental institution.

column3: The order is driven by a legal requirement to validate the passenger's documents before proceeding with other steps in the check-in process.

The process description indicates that checking the validity of documents must occur before cancelling the check-in process, as this is a requirement enforced by governmental laws and regulations regarding valid travel documentation that airlines must comply with.

The process description indicates that document validation must occur before processing payment, as it would be a waste of time and resources to process the payment if the underlying documents are not valid. This is likely a requirement mandated by governmental regulations, such as airport security protocols or financial transaction laws, rather than a self-imposed business rule or industry best practice.

The requirement to validate documents before check-in is likely due to governmental regulations or laws that the airline must adhere to, as the validity of travel documents is an important aspect of passenger security and immigration control.
The process description states that if the ticket or passport is not valid, the whole process can be cancelled, indicating a legal requirement to check the documents before loading the luggage.

column5: The process description indicates that the agent wants to make sure the baggage is weighed before canceling the check-in process, suggesting this is a rule set by the airline/organization that can be changed at their own discretion.

The process description indicates that the airline requires the baggage to be weighed before the payment is processed, which is a rule under the full jurisdiction of the airline as the stakeholder of the process.

The airline has a rule that the baggage needs to be weighed before the check-in can be completed. This is a business decision made by the airline stakeholders, and is not mandated by any governmental law or industry best practice.

column3: The process description states that there is a law that requires the weight of the luggage to be checked before it can be loaded onto the aircraft.
column6: The weight of the luggage needs to be known before it can be loaded, as the total weight of the luggage affects the aircraft's takeoff weight and loading calculations. This is a logical dependency, not just a procedural one.

column5: The process description states that no other activities should be performed after canceling a check-in, indicating this is a business rule set by the airline that can be changed at their discretion.

The process description clearly states that the airline wants the check-in process to be canceled before any other activities are performed. This is a rule that is under the full jurisdiction and discretion of the airline stakeholders. They can choose to change or discard this rule as they see fit.

The process description clearly states that 'after canceling a checkin instance, you should not perform any other activities'. This indicates that the order between Cancel check-in and Load luggage is a rule that is under the full jurisdiction of the stakeholders (the airline and its staff) and can be changed or discarded at their discretion.
The process description indicates that the airline requires the payment to be processed before the check-in of the luggage, as a rule set by the airline stakeholders.

The process description explicitly states that 'the airline wants us to only do the check-in if the other things are done to make sure that the payment is processed.' This indicates that the requirement to process the payment before loading the luggage is a rule under the full jurisdiction and control of the airline, which can be changed or discarded at their own discretion.

The process description indicates that the airline wants the Check-in luggage to be completed before the luggage is loaded onto the aircraft, suggesting that this ordering is a rule set by the stakeholders (the airline) and is under their full jurisdiction to change or discard as they see fit.
column6: The relationship between Check-in luggage and Load luggage is also due to a law of nature. The luggage needs to be physically present and processed through the Check-in before it can be loaded onto the aircraft. This is a logical and resource dependency, as the luggage cannot be loaded without first being checked in.
